DIV1.P: A WORD Against A New Election, THAT THE People of ENGLAND May See the Happy Difference between ENGLISH Liberty AND FRENCH Slavery; AND Consider WELL, before they make the EXCHANGE.
Printed in Year 1710.

DIV1.HEAD: A Word against a New Election, &c.
DIV1.P: IT is the Boast of a Party among us, when they Insult their Neighbours upon the late Distractions, and when they Threaten us with Dissolution of the Parliament, the Queen's turning Out her Ministry, and the like, That the People of England are gain'd to them; that they have got the Mob on their Side, and that they have opened the Nations Eyes. It seems absolutely necessary to enquire how far this Thing is true, and to put it into other Words a little, that we may see by it the State of the Nation.

The true meaning of the Thing is thus ex∣plain'd, viz. that this is their Hour and the Power, &c. That the Time is come upon us when God has peen pleased (no doubt vindictively) to give some People up to strong Delusions, that like the Men of Sodom, Blindness should over-spread great Part of the People. And to bring this to pass, a wicked Party of Men among us have, with too much Success, assisted the gene∣ral Defection; have first spread a Cloud over the Eyes of the People, and then dug the Pit
in their Way. By this Party some of the poor People have been brought to take Error for Truth, Falshood for Sincerity, Hypocrisy for Friendship, Bondage for Liberty; and in short, Darkness for Light.

In Religion, they have been fed with Words for Substance, Politicks for Doctrine, and Rail∣ing for Applicatiou; have been brought to for∣get Charity, Brotherly Forbearance and Mode∣ration, taking up Principles of Persecution, Fu∣ry, and Abherence of their Brethren.

In Government, they Embrace absolute Ty∣ranny, for Legal Monarchy, Hereditary Right, instead of Parliamentary Limitation, and Arbi∣trary Will, for Law, by which they are led Blindfold to practice Absolute Submission, with Pleasure, giving up Liberty, with Delight, like the True Tribe of Isacher, Couching▪ even be∣fore the Load is laid On. Court their own Chains, and Address their Soveraign for Slave∣ry.

But this has neither sunk so Deep, nor spread so Far, as some People Imagine; what they have hitherto gain'd, will not, we hope, prove so great an Advantage to them, when the People come to Discover, whether all these things Tend Indeed one would not have thought things so Absur'd as these, should gain any Ground a all among us. One would have thought, the Ty∣ranny we so lately Groan'd under, cou'd not be so Easily forgot; that the Revolution might ye Stare in their Faces. The Gibbets, on which their Murthered Relations were put to Death are scarce taken down; the Spikes that Empail'd
the Sculls and Quarters of the Nations Patriots, d the Martyrs of Liberty, are yet standing on our Gates, both in England and Scotland. he Fears of Popery; the Concern for Property, hich possess the very same People, who are ow Running back to Egypt, cannot but be fresh their Memories.

When Idolatry was erected in their Streets, nd the Mass stood Cheek by Joul with the Com∣on Prayer; when the Priests began to appear in heir Habits, and the Coul walk'd Hand in Hand ith the Circingle; when the Press advocated or the Grose, and the Papists debated their Case Public; when Pamphlets for Popery crowded he Streets, and the Papist misrepresented, was efended by Authority; when the Government as entirely Popish, and the Nobility began to go o Mass, to make good an Old Maxim of State, all'd Regis ad exempm

One would think (I say) these Times could not be so soon forgot, it is only Forgetfulness, the Power of these Delusions wants nothing, but to e a little wip'd off. The Memory of the Com∣mon People wants only to be Reviv'd, they on∣y want to have the Remembrance of these hings Restor'd; to have Popery and Slavery a∣gain brought into their View, the Wooden Shoes of France, the Inquisition Court of Spain, the High Commission Court of King James, set a ittle in their Sight again; if these things were done effectually, the Common People of Eng∣land would soon Return to their usual Integrity, the Scales would fall from their Eyes, and the Jacobites would have little cause to boast, that they had got the Mob on their Side.

Never let them promise themselves, that these things can consist with one another, the People of England can never be long Deluded, it cannot be imagin'd, that the same Poor People can pull down the Popish Mass-Houses to Day, and the Dissenting Meeting-Houses to Morrow; can Huzza for King William one time, and for Dr. Sacheverell another. They want only to have Matters set in a True Light, and their Eyes will open; they want only to know what they are doing, and who manages them; did they know the Designs of this wretched Party; did they see the Pit at the End of all these Things, they would Tear those People to Pieces, that have thus impos'd upon them, and brought them thus to Act, for that Party they Abhor.

Did the Honest Well-meaning People, that shouted that Fire-Brand into Shrewsbury; that hung out Flags for him at Bridgnorth; that trea∣ted him at Warwick, and waited on him in Form at Banbury; did they know, that at the same time, that he has taken the Oaths to Queen Anne, call'd God to Witness of his Zeal for Her Go∣vernment, and stiled himself a Champion of the Church. He has, in his more private Conversa∣tion, Drank on his Knees to the Prosperity of a Popish Pretender, Acknowledged him for his So∣veraign, Cursed the Protestant Succession, as a Damn'd Legacy by King William, and wish'd that Glorious Restorer of England's Liberties, should be Torn in Pieces by the Rabble.

These things, and many such are known, they can be prov'd uyon this Idol, who the People have been deluded to Worship; the Time is at
and, when they shall be made Publick. Can y Man believe, if this Wolf, in Sheeps Clo∣ing, had been stript, the Protestants of this ingdom could have Carress'd and Hugg'd him they have done? He would stink in their Nostrils, ey would be ashamed of their Blindness, and e would not dare to pass through those Places gain, or go back the same way he came, for ar of a Just Resentment from the People he had Abused.

This being the True State of our Case, the eople of England should be Inform'd a little, hey should see whose Drudgery they have been oing, how they have been Impos'd upon, what hey have done, what they are still doing, and his would bring them to their Wits again.

This Party having, with infinite Cunning, rought the Poor People to Espouse the Absur'd Doctrine of Non-Resistance, the Genuine Intro∣uction of Tyranny and Universal Bondage, it Requisite, in order to take off that Delusion, that we should let them see a little what Slavery is. what the Effects of Tyranny are, what the Difference s between a Legal Limited Government, where Property is Sacred, Justice Unfettered, and the Soveraignty of the Law Acknowledged; and a French Despotick Tyranny, where Non-Resisting Principles Subject the very Souls, as well as Bo∣dies, of the People, to the Arbitrary Lust of an Absolute Tyrant.

It is Requisite to let the People see, That the End of all these things is to Enslave us, to bring both our Religious and Civil Liberties into the same Condition, that the Subjects of France are now brought into.

To let them see what that Condition is, giv them a View of French Bondage, and Popish Go∣vernment, that they may know what it is, and consider how they should like it, how well i would suite with English Liberty, and wh mighty Gainers they would be by the Exchang
And this is the Design of the Paper.

To bring this down to the meanest Under∣standing, it seems necessary to enter into the short History of our present Circumstances, an give the People of England a View of their pre∣sent State, how it came to what it is, and what it may come to, if those People prevail.
We need not look back beyond the Revoluti By it, this Nation obtain'd some few things hardly worth Naming; and as some think, les worth Keeping, such as,

LIST.ITEM: Invading Popery Banish'd, and Turn'd out of Doors.
The Laws, in the Person of their Great Pro∣tector, King William, Guarded, and Justi made Sacred.
All this Secured by a Protestant Succession, and Clincht at Home, by a National Union.

DIV1.P: These are Things we gain'd by the Revolu∣tion.

These are the things the Enemies of the Re∣olution would take from us again: For this d, they Nourish Jacobitism among us, for this d, they rejoyce when the French prevail, and ok sad when they are beaten: For this, they ink the Health of the Pretender, as Dr. Sache∣rell himself has openly done: For this they urse the Memory of King William, for this Dr. cheverell publickly said at Birmingham, as has en proved upon Oath, that he hoped to see King illiam De Witted, That is, Torn in pieces, by the ob. For this, the same Reverend Dr. peaking King William, said he could forgive him any ing but that Damn'd Legacy, the Protestant succession, which He left us.

For this, the same Dr. has now set the Nation in Flame; For this, they raise Tumults, make Pro∣resses, foment Rabbles, and Mob the Dissenters: For this, they change Principles, change Hands, &c. nd the like: Remember Britains. 'Tis for this, ey are Treating, Caballing, and forming Parties or a New Election, that if possible, they may ring Men into Parliament, that will Give up e Constitution, abandon Property, expose Re∣gion, and prostitute the Virgin Liberties of this ation, to the ravishing Lust of a Popish Pre∣nder.

What is at stake then in your Election of Par∣ment Men? Your Religion, your Liberty, the evolution, the Succession, the Toleration, the Union? Consider Britains what you are a doing: hat have these things cost the Nation, that now ey should not be thought worth keeping? hat is there in French Bondage, that we
should be fond of restoring it? What Tempe have we found in Papists and High Flyers, whe they have been uppermost in the Nation?

How come France to groan under Tyranny How come the poor Husbandmen there to hav Lean Carcasles, dejected Countenances, an Wooden Shooes? How come the Gentry to b Slaves to the Court, depend upon the War, an seek all their Grandeur, in the assisting the King's Tyranny? How ca the heavy Impo∣sitions of the Tallie, the Capiiations, the Far of Salt, &c. for which they say what Sums thei Task-Masters impose; must buy Salt, wheth they can use it or no; pay 40 s. per Bushel fo it, and ha e the quantity forced upon them.

All this was brought upon them, by giving up their Liberties, by neglecting their Privilege when they had them, by suffering the Encroach∣ments of their Monarchs, and permitting th Tools of Tyranny, gradually to undermine an supplant them; in short, by choosing bad Mem∣bers of Parliament, and letting their Representa∣tives give up their Constitution.

France had once Laws, Privileges, Parliaments, Liberties, Charters, and all the advantages of Free Nation. Their Kings like ours, could levy no Taxes, force no unjust Burthens upon th People. The Estates of the Kingdom restrain'd the Ambition of their Princes, and prevented th Miseries of the Subjects for many Ages.

When they had Liberty, they had Wealth they were Rich, Flourishing and Happy; bu when they lost their National Priveleges, they Sunk into Misery. Slavery always brings Pover∣ty,
they go Hand in Hand together. Their Unlimited Monarchs, to support their Pride, Ambition, Avarice, and exorbitant Greatness to carry on their Unjust Wars, and to injure and ppress their weaker Neighbours, have made Havock of their own Subjects, have spent their Blood in one, and their Treasure in the other, till the poor People are reduced to the utmost Misery and distress. Their Goods, their per∣sons, their Families, their Blood, their Souls, are at the Absolute disposal of the Tyrant that Rules them: They must Worship God, but as le would have them, wear no Cloaths but what He permits them, Eat no Bread but what He leaves them: Nothing in France can be call'd the r own, all is the Kings, and all are Subjects to His Absolute Will.

Remember English Men! Compare this with your own Case, where every Man's House is his Castle, His Goods are His property, His Estate is his own, the QUEEN cannot command a Shilling, but by aw; not a Farthing raised but by Parliament, paid but by Legal Collection, nor employed when paid, but lyable to an Ac∣count to the Parliament.
Your Lives, your Religion, your Estates, your Liberties, are all secured by Law, and what you have, may truly be call'd your own.

What is the difference between You and the Poor French, You are Rich, they are Poor; You are Well Fed, they Starve; You have warm Houses, warm Clothes; they Perish with Cold, wear the worst of Clothes, Wooden Shooes, and Iron Chains; in short, you are alive, and they are dead.

Consider English Men: Learn once but to neg∣lect your Liberties, give up your Rights, and choose Representatives that will do the same. And France may say to You, as the Dead Man's Motto says to the Living.

Q.L: As Tou are, so was I;
As I am, so will You be.

DIV1.P: Now is the Time for you to look about you: Had your Fathers given up their Liberties, You had been Slaves, Beggars and Papists, as th French now are; and if you give them up, your Children will be so.

Nothing but Liberty preserves Religion here: Had not your Laws and Liberties been Rescued from Tyranny, in the Revolution, your Religion had not been rescued from Popery and Super∣stition; and when ever you give up your Liber∣ty to the Will of the Prince, you give up your Religion with it of Course.
Nothing can secure Your Liberties or Religion, but your choosing Members of Parliament, who will defnd the Revolution, preserve the Tolera∣tion, and secure the Protestant Succession.

Consider then, whether your Liberty, your Religion, your Constitution, your Posterity, do not all call upon you to choose such Men as will preserve them against all manner of Invasions, that your Children may never curse you for be∣traying them to Bondage, or your God reproach and punish you with taking that invaluable Blessing from you, I mean the Protestant Reli∣gion, because you cared not to preserve or im∣prove it when you had it.
Unhappy Britain, that has all her present and ture Felicity for this World depending upon trifling a Thing as the Breath of the Mouths f her Freemen and Freeholders.
Yet Happy Britain, that has all her valuable iberties, all her Blessings committed to her wn keeping, and cannot be ruin'd but by her wn Consent.

Why do your Enemies plot, contrive, manage, is-manage, &c. but knowing this Truth that is must be your own Act and Deed, if you are de∣royed: They hope so to blind you, that you ay pull down your own House on your Heads, nd do the Work to their Hands.

This acknowledges their Weakness, the low∣ess of their Interest, smallness of their Power, nd badness of their Cause. They cannot lead ou by Numbers, they cannot drive you by force, they dare not try it; they have no way eft but to delude you by Cunning, and bring you to ruin Blindfold upon your own Mischief.
The Queen has now dissolved the Parliament, nd directed a new Choice: A Dissolution does y no means dissolve the Right of Choosing, or the Necessity of Parliaments.
Let us examin the Case a little, and offer som Things to your Consideration. Some are alarm'd t the Dissolution; some rejoyce at it.
No Man need trouble himself at the Dissolu∣ion, if the Freeholders and Electors do but pre∣erve, not their Right of Electing, but their enses in Election; and that is the End of this Discourse.
Enquire then who are they that rejoyce at the Dissolution of the last Parliament; and are not all the Jacobites, Papists, and the Enemies of the Revolution, of that Number?

If Jacobites, if Papists, if High-Flyers rejoyce at the Dissolution of the last Parliament, it is a most necessary Hint to us, and makes it Natural to enquire what it is they can rejoyce at, but the Hopes, that by fomenting our Divisions, en∣flaming our Parties, and embroiling us one with another, they may get such Members chosen as may have less Zeal against Popery, less Steadi∣ness against the Pretender, be less careful of our Liberties, less sollicitous for the Nations Peac¦less warm in Defence of the Protestant Successi∣on, and for Preservation of the Union, than they were that went before. Let us descend to Par∣ticulars.

The Jacobites can have no other View in it than to make easy the Restoration of the Preten∣der, whom they acknowledge for their lawful King. They could not be Jacobites, if they did not desire this; and they can have no other Reason for desiring a New Parliament, but in hopes of some lucky Chance, some happy Turn, as they call it, in favour of their Party. The last Parliament they found by Experience would not do the Work, another may; and therefore they desire a Dissolution, and rejoyce in it.

Papists can have no other View in it, than to make easy the Recovery of French Power, in which alone Popery can have any prospect of returning upon us in this Nation: A vigorous pursuit of the War, to the entire Reduction of
France, must be fatal to the Popish Interest in ritain, whose only hope rests upon Assistance om the French, either by restoring the Pre∣nder, a Popish Tool bred up in Superstition, by any other Method; of which the exorbi∣nt Greatness of France would never want eans.

If any honest Men may be satisfied with the issolution of the last Parliament, in hopes that may cool and allay the Heats and Divisions which are come to such a satal hight among us, hat might endanger the Publick Peace, and that hey thought the Change of the Parliament the est, if not the only way, to prevent those Mis∣hiefs.

Such will above all Things desire that we hould choose Men of peaceable Principles, Men f Temper and Moderation to succeed; other∣wise the End will not be answer'd; and the Sa∣isfaction such have reaped from the Dissolution will be entirely disappointed.
This will farther be made plain to our Under∣standings, if we examine what the several Par∣ties aim at in the Affair of a new Election.

LIST.ITEM: 3. What it is honest Men desire?

DIV1.P:
1. Her Majesty, as all honest Men believe, de∣fires to put an end to our Divisions; and having found the Heat of Parties run high, has dissolv∣ed the House to dissolve those Heats, if possible.
We cannot doubt but her Majesty sincerely aim at the Ease and Quiet of her Subjects, and o the Government, even in this Dissolution. Go grant all the pious and just Designs of her M∣jesty in this Dissolution, for the Ease, Quiet an Safety of her People, and the Protestant Su∣cession, may be answer'd

But this leads directly to the present Case presses Home the Arguments made use of, an doubly urges, warns and exhorts, the Freehol∣ders and Freemen of Britain, to be very carefu in their Choice; to send up such Men as ma particularly farther, and effectually carry on H Majesties most Christian and pious Design This can never be done, by choosing Men Factious, Contentious, Anti Revolution princi∣ples: Men of disquiet, and unpeaceable Dispo∣sitions, can never carry on Her Majesties piou design, of Uniting all Her Subjects in Peace an Union; to exhort you to Choose Men of peace Men of clear Thought, Loyal Hearts, unbyass'd Fidelity, steady Heads, and found Judgments▪ This is to exhort You, to answer the Ends o Her Majesty, in this Dissolution.

No Men have the Impudence to suggest to You, that it can be pleasing to Her Majesty, that you should choose Jacobites and High Flyers The first, Declared Enemies to Her Government▪ the Last, Men that disown in practice, However they pretend to come in by their taking Oaths, the Right our Gracious QUEEN has to Govern▪ and are profest Enemies to that peace and Moderation, by which Her Majesty does Go∣vern us.

It would be an Affront to Her Majesty, to hink, that it could please Her, to choose those hat declare War against the Justice, either of er Title or Administration. The High Flyers this Nation, are equally Enemies of the Go∣ernment, with the Jacobites. No Man can ggest, that Her Majesty desires the People of ritain should choose such as these.

The Mobs that have Insulted the Peace of Majesties Dominions, and bid defiance to er Royal Justice, have no ways been pleasing Her Majesty. Dr. Sacheverell▪ in all his Va∣ties, has not had the least Countenance from e Queen, Her Majesty is too much a Lover Her Subjects Tranquility, and has too much Heart, the Quiet of Her Realm, and the od Order of Her Government, to approve such Follies. It cannot be suggested, that Her ajesty can be pleas'd with Riots and Disor∣rs, or that Electing such People as have foment∣ that Criminals riotous Behaviour can be agree∣e to the Queen; much less, was i in Her Ma∣ties Design, when She resolved to give Her ople an Opportunity of a New Election, that ey should run into Riots and Confusion.

Can any one believe, without greatly onting Her Majesty, that it can be agreea∣ to Her Just and Religious Designs, for the od of her People, that we should choose Men Dividing, Quarrelling and Persecuting Prin∣les? These are the Men, that instead of heal∣ our Breaches, will widen and encrease them: t instead of Preserving the Union lately made
among us, would Dissolve it, and renew our National Animosities; which Her Majesty was so Zealous to lay Asleep, that She told us often She thought the Union of Her Two Kingdom one of the greatest Felicities of Her Reign Those therefore who have express'd their Viru¦lent Spirits against the Union; against the Pro∣testant Limitation of the Crown, by Parliamen∣tary Authority; and against the Quiet and Peace of their Country; cannot be such as the Queen can desire should be Chosen, while we know H Majesty has at Heart, the General as well as Par∣ticular Union of Her People.

It would be needless to say to the English Fr holders, that the Queen does not desire they should choose the Enemies of the Revolution to represent them in Parliament; were it not th there's a Party of Men among us, who preten mighty things for the Queen, and boast of the Loyalty to her Majesty; and yet Curse that Glo∣rious Transaction, in which the Liberty of th Protestant Nation, to exclude Papists from th Crown, was Asserted; and that have taken up on them to Decry that Parliamentary Right o Limitting the Succession to the Crown, by which Her Present Majesty Reigns, add without which Her Royal Title would be publickly Dispute and Uncertain.

2. Come we next to examine what it is th our Enemies desire in the ensuing Election What is the Expectation of our French, Popis and Jacobite Enemies? The Hope of whic
akes them rejoyce at the Dissolution of the arliament, and triumph over us, on the Occa∣on of a New Election. These People have gi∣en you plain Discoveries of what they desire in New Election: They desire you should choose en that would give up the Constitution, Sacri∣ce Liberty, Exalt Prerogative, and Enslave you d your Posterity.

More Particularly, they would have you choose eople that would declare the Hereditary Right f the Crown, against Parliamentary Limitati∣n; and thereby make way for the Pretender, hose Legitamacy they are now very busy in maintaining.

They would have you Choose People who ear an implacable and irreconcileable Hatred o the House of Hannover; who reproach the Revolution, with bringing in Dutch Men and Foreigners; and pretend we have a King of ur own, who, as they call it, has an Indefe∣eble Title.

They would have you Choose People, who re so far from a Temper and Moderation t for the present Circumstances, that they rofess an inveterate Abhorrence to their Bre∣thren of differing Opinions in Religion: That re so far from a Christian Tenderness, that hey are for leaving Dissenters with the Devil nd his Angels; and have declared already for Persecution, under the Notion of Wholesom everitys, See Dr. Sacheverell▪s Sermon. . 8.

They would have you Choose People, who are so far from a Spirit of Union with Scotland, that they would have that Free Nation, reduced by Force of Arms, and with∣out any regard to Justice and Right, would have them made Hewers of Wood, and Drawers of Water, only because they are Pres∣byterians; and adhere Steadily to the Rights they Claim and Possess.

Lastly, if they cannot get such as these, then they desire you should Choose such Peo∣ple as would Divide, Embroil and Confound us, run us up to Tumults, Riots, and all manner of Confusion; Men of Violence and Fury, who neither Love Peace, nor will per∣mit others to enjoy it, hoping that out of those Confusions, some advantage may be made, for the Interest of France, and some Room found out, to squeeze in their Popish Pretender.

These are the Men that the Enemies of your Queen and Country would have you choose and if you have a mind to bring in Poperty, to restore French Tyranny, to dethrone your Protestant Queen, to Crown the Perkinite, and deliver France from being reduc'd by the Confederates: then indeed these are the Men the Freeh lders of Britain ought to choose to represent them.

3. Now let us see what the honest People of this Island d sire in a new Election; if they
ve Eeyes in their Heads, if they please to ben their Understandings, and look about em; or, if they cannot see for themselves, they please to listen to the Advice of those at can see for them, they will make a Choice fferent from all these, and thereby effectually appoint the Expectations of France, extin∣ish the Hopes of Jacobitism, and defeat the nds which some have own'd they have had desiring a Dissolution.
In order to this, 'tis earnestly recommend∣ to the Freeholders of Britain to cast their yes upon the Gentlemen who profer their ervice, on either Side, in the approaching Electi∣, and enquire▪
Who are they that have embrac'd the Revolu∣on, and vigorously withstood and resisted Po∣ish Arbitrary Princes in Defence of their Countries Liberty?

Who are they, that tho' sincere constant Members of the Church of England, have yet estifyed so much Christian Charity to their eaker Brethren, differing from them in some oints, as to express their Tenderness for them y establishing a legal Toleration.
Who are they that in Parliament laid the oundation of a lasting Peace between these wo Protestant Kingdoms of England and cotland in the late Happy Union.

Who are they that have from Time to Tim zealously asserted the Interest of their Country in Parliament, in setting the Rights of the People by a Parliamentary Authority, in case of the Succession of the House of Hanover.

Who are they that have vigorously support∣ed the Queen, and born the chief Weight and Burthen in this edious and desperate Wa choosing rather to continue and carry on the said War at an immense Charge, than to yield the least point to our French and Popish Enemies.

These are the Men qualified to represent this Nation in Parliament: These are the Men where-ever they are to be found, who the Free∣holders, if they are in their Wits, will choose, and who alone can save this Nation from Popery and Jacobitism.

If such Men are chosen, the Queen is safe, the Laws will be preserved, Justice protected, the hopes of a French Pretender will dye, Re∣ligion will be establish'd, English Liberty be maintain'd, and France must submit.

But if not, if ye choose High Flyers, if you send up raging Jacobites, Men of Tyrannic, Dividing Principles; Men that can persecute their Brethren for Trifles, and will give up Constitution Right for Arbitrary Hereditary Claim: Then Honest Freeholders, Remember You set Fire to your own Houses, you Undermine your own Privileges, you Pull Down your
otestant QUEEN, you say Backward all ur Laws of Liberty, you Brand your De¦erer King William, for an Usurper, and ke a Witches Prayer of the Revolution.

Then farewell Liberties, farewell Privileges, ewell Free Parliaments, farewell Limited Mo∣rchies, farewll Protestant Succession, farewell oleration, farewell Union, farewell QUEEN, d at last farewell Protestant Religion.

These will be succeeded by Tyranny, Arbi∣ary Power Despotic Government, dispensing with Law, perverting Justice, plundering the ubjects, Murthering the Innocent, Reforma∣on by Dragoons; and at last Popery.
All which, is earnestly recommended to the rotestants of this United Nation to Consider, t the approaching Election.
